front.title: The text/syslog Media Type for Syslog

abstract.t: The syslog protocol is used to convey event notification messages across the network. This document specify a stored format for Syslog information.

section.title: Introduction and Background
section.t: The syslog protocol specify the wire format of standardized syslog, but it does not specify a format for stored data. This document describe how syslog messages are stored in text files in a format that is close to the on-the-wire format.

There are two main issues that this document addresses: the important information on syslog priority and facility is usually discarded in existing implementations and there are no common rules for control character escaping provided. This document offers guidelines for both.
The encoding outlined in this document can be used both with legacy syslog as described in and standardized syslog.

section.title: Syslog Format
section.t: The textual representation is on-the-wire format as documented in except for the control character handling describe below. The PRI field MUST be included inside the textual representation, as discussed in . The ABNF rule for on-the-wire syslog messages is SYSLOG-MSG.
Each syslog message MUST be delimited by a CRLF trailer.

Control characters inside the textual representation MUST be escaped. Characters %x00 to %x1F and %x7f MUST be encoded as "#ooo" where "ooo" is the threee-digit octal representation of the characters' numerical code. The character "#" (%x23) MUST be encoded as "##". Please note that this encoding is consistent with what many implementations already use. We have selected this encoding in the hope that it be the least intrusive one.

section.title: IANA Considerations
section.t: The registration template as documented in follows:
Optional parameters: The "charset" parameter MAY be used as discussed in , and is normally UTF-8.
Encoding considerations: 8bit, to preserve UTF-8 data.

Security considerations: Syslog information may be security relevant, and could warrant integrity and even confidentiality protection. Solutions to this problem is outside the scope of this document, but we note the existence of PGP/MIME and S/MIME.
